Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2008 11:41PM Daffodil wrote: If your bed is high enough off the floor, getting up will be easy. Bed risers cost $20.00 or so and may make all the difference! Back rest pillow is good idea~~~good base for building your nest! Small soft pillows for under your arms are a godsend; try the ones with microbeads. (Brookstone) I am still using them to cushion expanders, which come out next week.

Posts.Content: Oct 26, 2008 03:36AM Daffodil wrote: A Sunday morning poem for Deb by an Alaskan: PRAISE BE Praise be to flowered flannel that softens and fades with age. Praise to checkered slippers knitted by elderly aunts from left-over yarn, thick slippers to cushion & warm our wandering feet. Praise to happy pom-poms, to antique lace; praise to hooded, over-sized robes with rolled sleeves; floor- length robes of terry & fleece. Praise to satin & silk; praise to clinging fabrics carefully folded into ribboned boxes by hopeful lovers & well- wishing friends. Praise to boxers and too-big T-shirts, snatched from the closets of intimate strangers. Praise to high- heeled slippers & slippers shaped like rabbits. Blessed be all that keeps us warm, alley cats & pomeranians, cuddlers, snugglers, back- sleepers, side-sleepers, spooners, quilted duvets & comforters: Praised be. Â  Â

Posts.Content: Nov 10, 2008 03:24AM Daffodil wrote: Article quoted in US magazine 11/06/08: Christina Applegate says fighting breast cancer "sucks," but you shouldn't feel sorry for her. "I still have quite a process until this is done," the actress says in the new issue of TV Guide. "Yes, it's hard. It sucks. But I'm not a victim." She will undergo reconstructive surgery near her 37th birthday, at the end of November. She had a double mastectomy in July. Applegate - a workaholic who clocks 14 to 16 hour days on Samantha Who - changed her outlook on life after her spring diagnosis. "I started looking for a beach house the day I found out I had this little disease," she says. "You just kind of go, 'What are you waiting for to get the things that you want and the things you dream of?' "I don't own tomorrow or yesterday - today is all I've got," she adds. "And if I don't make today good, then I'm only gonna' be p--ssed off tomorrow!"
Posts.Title: Christina Applegate my new hero KiminJax Daffodil

Posts.Content: Dec 10, 2008 04:41PM Daffodil wrote: Dear Rhonda: I had a public appearance 2 1/2 weeks after my bilateral w/reconstruction (but there wasn't much there). A couple of days before, DH drove me a recommended health boutique, where a very nice woman fitted me with a good bra (wide sides & back, built-up straps). I used to wear a 36 B; this one was 38 due to swelling I still had. It had a light foam liner for smoothness and soft pockets for the polyester pouffs. She chose "small" pouffs and took away stuffing until I had a nice "presentation"~~~I looked normal and nice in clothes! I didn't buy any special camisoles for drains, as I didn't have to go anywhere much except doctors' offices. When I did, I wore the bra, which was as comfortable as you could expect. In my case, as the fills increased, I removed more "stuffing" and continued to look pretty good! It cost about $50, which insurance should cover. Good luck to you!!
Posts.Title: Questions about what to wear after bilat. RhondaM Mykidsmom

Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2009 10:40AM Daffodil wrote: I had BM and reconstruction, but bought a mastectomy bra with pouffs to wear during the process. I just sent it to my sister (thanks, Grandmother, for this legacy) with new pouffs. OneÂ can be adjusted to match the other side, and if there's weight gain or loss, you can add or subtract the polyfill stuffing. It's pretty comfortable and the styling makes for good coverage and support. You can see the difference when you try to wear a regular bra; you need the wider bands and straps to make up for swelling, etc. Insurance should cover. I bought mine at a "health boutique" with a very kind fitter, and walked a runway at my cancer luncheon 2 1/2 weeks after surgery~~which was one year ago today! Blessings and good luck!

Posts.Content: Sep 5, 2008 01:18AM - edited Sep 7, 2008 03:33AM by Daffodil Dear Sumbunny: I wanted to tell you that my surgeon, a top-rated doctor in this area, does ONLY excisional biopsies, i.e. lumpectomies. He believes that the needle may pierce cancer cells, sending them flying into your system. The surgery was performed in his office under anesthesia, and I came home and got on the computer!! I could have stopped there and had radiation, but he strongly urged a more aggressive surgery for my particular situation, ageÂ and family history. We will hope for aÂ benign outcome. If you need more info, there are incredibly knowledgeable women on this board. Good luck!

Posts.Content: Nov 9, 2008 11:38AM Daffodil wrote: I don't have lymphedema, but I do have shoulder and wrist pain.,,,,,,and just massage therapist work on it~~~same fears as the rest of you, including a repeat of the rotator cuff surgery I had on other arm last year---ouch! I finally returned to orthopedist: wrist is metacarpal something arthritis (wrist brace and cortisone shot);shoulder is tendonitis, of a form often seen in women with mastectomies (PT). Arimidex doesn't help, of course!!

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2009 05:05AM Daffodil wrote: Dear Lord, You know my friend Dec CÂ so much better than I do. You know her sickness and the burden she carries. You also know her heart. Lord, I ask you to be with my friend now, working in her life. Let your will be done in Deb's life. Lord, I pray for my friend because your Word says I should pray for her healing. I believe you hear this earnest prayer from my heart and that it is powerful because of your promise. I have faith in you to heal my friend, but I also trust in the plan you have for her life. Lord, I don't always understand your ways, and why my friend has to suffer, but I trust you. I ask that you look with mercy and grace toward my friend Deb C. Nourish her spirit and soul in this time of suffering and comfort her with your presence. LetÂ Deb CÂ know you are there with her and her familyÂ through this difficulty. And may you be glorified in her life and also in mine. Amen
